question.title: How can I work around this apparent EhCache deadlock?

node.contents: Turns out that this question is invalid. I had interpreted this documentation (http://ehcache.org/documentation/user-guide/jta#performance) as indicating that explicit locks don't use Segment based locking, but turns out that's not true. This deadlock was caused by my code, there was a lock release that wasn't in a finally() block.

astNode.text: Turns out that this question is invalid. node.contents: why don't you answer your own question if you already figured it out so it won't be present in the unanswered questions?

astNode.text: why don't you answer your own question if you already figured it out so it won't be present in the unanswered questions?

node.contents: Using ehCache 2.4.4, I seem to have gotten into a deadlock on the ehCache Segment object. From other logging, I know that the 'waiting thread', 1694 last ran anything 9 hours before this stack trace was generated. In the meantime, 1696 has gone and done a lot of other work, so this lock is definitely being held errantly.

astNode.text: Using ehCache 2.4.4, I seem to have gotten into a deadlock on the ehCache Segment object. From other logging, I know that the 'waiting thread', 1694 last ran anything 9 hours before this stack trace was generated. In the meantime, 1696 has gone and done a lot of other work, so this lock is definitely being held errantly.

node.contents: I'm pretty confident that I am not directly locking any Segment instances directly, so I assume this is some kind of issue internal to the library. Any ideas?

astNode.text: I'm pretty confident that I am not directly locking any Segment instances directly, so I assume this is some kind of issue internal to the library. Any ideas?

node.contents: If that's really the case, you can mark this post as answer. Simply click on the big check mark symbol below the votes counter on the left of the answer - that way you indicate the question is answered :)

astNode.text: If that's really the case, you can mark this post as answer. Simply click on the big check mark symbol below the votes counter on the left of the answer - that way you indicate the question is answered :)

node.contents: Turns out that calls like Cache.acquireWriteLockOnKey end up obtaining a lock on the internal Segment, so this apparent deadlock was caused by a .unlock call that wasn't in a finally block.

astNode.text: Turns out that calls like Cache.acquireWriteLockOnKey end up obtaining a lock on the internal Segment, so this apparent deadlock was caused by a .unlock call that wasn't in a finally block.

node.contents: Editorial comment: It also implies that you can get contention trying to lock two different keys that just happened to be in the same Segment, which is pretty unfortunate.

astNode.text: Editorial comment: It also implies that you can get contention trying to lock two different keys that just happened to be in the same Segment, which is pretty unfortunate.
